info.game_comments:
2000-B College Championship quarterfinal game 2.  
From the University of Washington in Seattle.

(1, 1).clue: Charles Stone III's short film "True" was the inspiration for the series of Bud spots with this catchphrase

(2, 1).clue: In 1977 this Florida city replaced its old capitol building with a new high-rise capitol

(3, 1).clue: Computer hard drives are usually measured in GBs, which are these

(4, 1).clue: Repo, as in "They can't repo my car because I owe ten lousy payments!", is short for this

(1, 2).clue: Cartoon Network enlisted Bob Dole for this rabbit's campaign for the presidency

(2, 2).clue: The name of this Southwestern capital is Spanish for "holy faith"

(3, 2).clue: This metric unit is equivalent to 1.056 quarts

(4, 2).clue: Insert 1 letter in "debt" to get this, a bookkeeping entry for money you owe

(6, 2).clue: State where you'll find the lighthouse seen here

(1, 3).clue: This "Spin City" & "Family Ties" star sold fishing reels in Japanese ads

(2, 3).clue: Abraham Lincoln moved to this capital city in 1837

(3, 3).clue: The symbol for this unit of electrical resistance is the Greek letter omega

(4, 3).clue: These popular student loans are named for a Vermont senator

(6, 3).clue: Whoop-ee!  The tallest bird native to North America is a species of this

(1, 4).clue: In 1999 this character came out of retirement to peddle a new Charmin

(2, 4).clue: America's oldest public art museum, the Wadsworth Atheneum, is in this city whose name contains the word "art"

(3, 4).clue: Subtract an "E" from 1,760 yards & you get this measurement for one-thousandth of an inch

(4, 4).clue: A time during which late payments aren't penalized, or the years 1956-1982 in Monaco

(5, 4).clue: Mr. Spock of "Star Trek" feels the urge to mate

(6, 4).clue: It's the opposite of wax, when referring to phases of the moon

(1, 5).clue: Barnes & Noble--Bam!--sent this chef out--Bam!--into people's houses--Bam!--to push his book

(2, 5).clue: In 1957 this city's Central High was at the center of a desegregation battle

(3, 5).clue: The name of this system of weights & measures comes from the Old French for "goods of weight"

(4, 5).clue: This partner of "forget" is what Bono wants Western nations to do with Third World debt

(5, 5).clue: An ordinary jubilee year in the Roman Catholic Church

(6, 5).clue: It means to fabricate or imitate, or to pretend, as ignorance

(1, 1).clue: Born in 69 B.C., she was the daughter of the ruler known as Ptolemy the Flute Player

(2, 1).clue: In "Scream 2" this actress' character, Sidney Prescott, is a student at Windsor College

(3, 1).clue: "Life These Days" finds Garrison Keillor telling "Stories From" this title place

(4, 1).clue: Worn today by both men & women, the coat variety seen here is known by this "military" name

(5, 1).clue: PBS fans know that "Evening at Pops" refers to this city's Pops

(6, 1).clue: If you're a professor, reader or lecturer, you're also a "Jolly Good" one of these scholars

(1, 2).clue: Before he went into politics, Cicero used his oratorical skills in this profession

(2, 2).clue: This singer played a college professor in love with portly prof. Sherman Klump in "Nutty Professor II: The Klumps"

(3, 2).clue: His novellas include "Hearts in Atlantis", "The Body" & "Apt Pupil"

(4, 2).clue: He's the clothing designer who gave us Tommy Girl cologne

(5, 2).clue: Schubert & Gounod both wrote works called this, Latin for "Hail Mary"

(6, 2).clue: It's an Oxford academic, as well as the title of that infamous Mr. Corleone

(1, 3).clue: The Second Punic War ended in 201 B.C when this Carthaginian general made peace with Rome

(2, 3).clue: "Rudy" tells the true story of Rudy Ruettiger, who realized his dream of playing football for this university

(3, 3).clue: This Brad Pitt film was based on Norman MacLean's fly-fishing novella of the same name

(4, 3).clue: Seen here, these trousers bear the name of the island where they first became popular

(5, 3).clue: This Italian term for the deepest range of male voice often precedes "profondo" or "profundo"

(6, 3).clue: The rivalry between students & city dwellers is rhymingly known as "Town &" this

(1, 4).clue: Of Samos, Davos or Junior, the island on which Pythagoras was born

(2, 4).clue: This "Ferris Bueller" star meets up with Marlon Brando & a komodo dragon in "The Freshman"

(3, 4).clue: His complete short stories were published in 1998 in the Finca Vigia edition

(4, 4).clue: Trading on its century-old name, this Ohio company abbreviated A&F sells casual clothes & accessories

(5, 4).clue: Andre Previn composed a cello sonata for this noted musician seen here

(6, 4).clue: You may do this in polite company; it means to register or enroll at a college

(1, 5).clue: Ashurbanipal turned this capital city of Assyria into a cultural mecca

(2, 5).clue: This "American Beauty" seen here is enamored of her professor, Greg Kinnear, in the 2000 flick "Loser"

(3, 5).clue: "The Angel on the Roof" compiles 37 years of stories by this man who wrote "Affliction" & "The Sweet Hereafter"

(4, 5).clue: Lycra is a brand of this, the sturdy, non-rubber elastic fabric in use here

(5, 5).clue: Rossini's "Otello" debuted 71 years before this composer's more famous "Otello" opera

(6, 5).clue: 3-letter Yank slang for one's physique; at Oxford it's short for a centuries old library

(0, 0).clue: As a warning to Congress, president James Garfield named his dog this
